awd_titl_txt: I-Corps: Magnetic steering and tracking for minimally invasive medical procedures
awd_abstract_narration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this I-Corps project is the development of technology that enables a vast variety of surgical/interventional procedures including intra-vascular/airways/GI tract and intra-tissue/organ procedures with minimal tissue damage and without any exposure to radiation. In particular, magnetic steering can be used in all medical procedures that involve needles or catheters such as biopsy, stent placement, balloon angioplasty, and microelectrode array placement in the brain. The tracking system can also be used along with any tethered medical device. In addition, this technology will benefit patients through eliminating human error and shorter waitlists; interventional surgeons through eliminating radiation exposure, improving catheter/needle manipulation, and enabling real-time, high-resolution, 3D tracking; and hospitals through reducing chances of adverse events and lawsuits and catching up to the demand. Thus, this system is a fit for the interventional surgical robot market as it addresses the pain points of the customers, end-users, and patients. 

This I-Corps project is based on the development of technology to improve catheter/needle steerability while eliminating the need for X-ray imaging and radiation exposure. The novelty of the magnetic steering technology is in replacing the conventional mechanical pushing with a magnetic pulling mechanism that significantly improves controlled tip placement and steering in the difficult-to-reach areas in the body. Moreover, there is no need for a load-bearing needle shaft and it can be made of arbitrarily soft materials. This, in turn, eliminates the excessive tissue damage and enables the steering of the catheter/needle on high-curvature 3D paths and accessing locations that are not accessible with current robotic technologies. In addition, the current technology for tracking steerable surgical tools in interventional procedures is X-ray fluoroscopy which suffers from excessive radiation exposure and the inability to capture the image of soft tissues. The proposed tracking system is designed to directly address these pain points. Besides, the tracking system contributes to the stability of the magnetic pulling mechanism by restraining the deployment speed of the catheter/needle. Thus, the proposed technology significantly improves the state-of-the-art catheter/needle steering and tracking and directly addresses the pain points of conventional technologies.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Technology, Innovation, and Partnerships

por.por_cntn:
This project focused on developing a groundbreaking surgical robotic system designed to enhance precision and safety in interventional medical procedures. This project leveraged magnetic manipulation and advanced tracking technology to address challenges in minimally invasive surgeries, offering significant intellectual and societal benefits.

Intellectual Merit
The project aimed to create a magnetic steering system for catheters and needles, coupled with a radiation-free tracking solution, advancing the state of surgical robotics. Current technologies rely heavily on mechanical manipulation and X-ray fluoroscopy, which pose risks such as radiation exposure and limited precision. Our approach involved attaching a magnetized tip to surgical tools and steering them with external magnetic forces applied by robotic systems. This innovation allows for precise navigation through complex anatomical pathways while minimizing tissue damage. Additionally, the radiation-free tracking system, using fiber Bragg grating (FBG) sensors, ensures safe and accurate localization of tools during procedures.

The project resulted in several key technical milestones:

  1. Development of functional prototypes demonstrating enhanced tool maneuverability and precision in simulated environments.
  2. Validation of a novel tracking system that eliminates radiation exposure while providing high-resolution tool localization.
  3. Securing two issued, four pending, and six provisional patents to protect intellectual property rights.

Broader Impacts
The societal benefits of this technology are extensive. By reducing the need for X-ray imaging, the system minimizes radiation exposure for both patients and medical staff. The enhanced precision lowers the risk of complications, shortens recovery times, and improves overall surgical outcomes. These advancements align with broader healthcare goals of reducing costs and increasing accessibility.

The commercialization potential of this innovation is significant. Our team engaged with over 100 stakeholders, including surgeons, hospital administrators, and medical device companies, to understand the market needs and refine the product. The technology is poised to penetrate the rapidly growing market for surgical robotics and tracking systems, with a potential global impact on healthcare delivery.

Collaborative and Educational Contributions
The project fostered interdisciplinary collaboration between engineering and medical fields, including partnerships with Mayo Clinic and Barrow Neurological Institute. These collaborations provided invaluable clinical insights, accelerating the path toward real-world application. Additionally, the I-Corps program enabled the team to develop entrepreneurial skills, bridging the gap between scientific innovation and commercial viability.

The work also contributed to education and workforce development. Students and researchers involved in the project gained hands-on experience in cutting-edge biomedical engineering, robotics, and entrepreneurship, preparing them for impactful careers in academia, industry, and healthcare.

In summary, this project has made substantial contributions to the fields of surgical robotics and interventional medicine, offering a safer, more effective alternative to traditional procedures. By addressing critical challenges in healthcare, it represents a transformative step toward improving patient care and advancing medical technology.

 


Last Modified: 01/04/2025
Modified by: Hamidreza Marvi
